cells.data:
Some theorems

$p$ prime and $p \mid a_1 \dots a_n \implies p$ divides one of the $a_i$

If $\gcd(a,b) = 1, a \mid c, b \mid c, \implies ab \mid c$

Proved uniqueness of prime factorization

Congruences:
Multiplication and addition works fine.
If we want to divide--
$ax \equiv ay \mod n \land \gcd(a,n) \equiv 1 \implies x \equiv y \mod n$

How to solve $ax \equiv b \mod m$
Need to find $\bar{a}$ s.t. $a\bar{a} \equiv 1 \mod m$

When is this unsolvable?
Suppose $a,m$ are relatively prime ($\gcd(a,m) = 1$)
$\exists \bar{a}$ s.t. $a\bar{a} \equiv 1 \mod m$
and $\bar{a}$ is unique $\mod m$ (This follows from application of BÃ©zout's Theorem)
